item.title: U.S Army
item.dc:creator: @Yz85Racer Yz85Racer
item.description:
@Yz85Racer wrote:

[quote=“MujaheD, post:84, topic:312213”][quote author=Lothy link=topic=408643.msg3080048#msg3080048 date=1262098220]

It’s no secret that this country, Australia, is fucked if we ever get invaded. We were fucked from the moment that the Howard government decided to do the gun buy back in 1996.
We’re even more fucked, actually, because there’s such a negative stigma surrounding guns and the like in this country that most people don’t want to possess firearms.
Try sitting in a high school class room and talking about guns; you’ll promptly find that the majority of people find them ‘evil’ (as if guns have an agenda of their own), just as I did a few years ago.

Good work on pointing out the obvious, though.

Problem is, we have too many wannabe gangsters in Australia to legalize guns.

You don’t get it, and neither did the people I went to school with. In fact, I’d be willing to bet that they still don’t ‘get it’.
Here it is, in black and white: Guns are illegal in Australia, but they’re still out there and they’re quite easy to get.

There are many firearms unaccounted for and floating around in Australia. This isn’t publicised enough, and most people believe that this isn’t the case because of the laws in place.
Outlaws were dubbed outlaws for a reason. If they’re going to break half a dozen laws doing whatever they do, they may as well break one more by possessing a firearm.

The bottom line is that they’re still there, but the law abiding people in the country are at a disadvantage by following the laws.
Gun control does not work in a society with too many unpoliced or ineffectively policed means of transportation of goods. Neither does prohibition of anything.
Once they make it to shore, they’re there for good (or until destroyed).
The fact that guns were legal for so long only exacerbates the problem of controlling them.
[/quote]

The thing is, in Australia guns aren’t completely banned. In fact, it’s only if you request a license for the purpose of self-defense or other purposes deemed as illegitimate that you’re not allowed to own one. Even when it comes to self-defense there are some exceptions(according to wikipedia).

According to Wikipedia:

‘For each firearm a “Genuine Reason” must be given, relating to pest control, hunting, target shooting, or collecting. Self-defense is not accepted as a reason for issuing a licence, though it may be legal under certain circumstances to use a legally-held firearm for self-defence.’

To me this seems pretty reasonable.

I’m not entirely sure under what ‘circumstances’ possessing a firearm for self defense is allowed, but I personally don’t think your regular Joe needs a firearm to be safe. I personally only ever lived in Melbourne and as far as I’m concerned, firearms are completely unnecessary when it comes to self-defense. Moreover, I would be very concerned to see the people I lived around have access to them.

But my opinion is only limited to my experiences within Melbourne. I can imagine that if your occupation involves traveling in the outback i.e you’re a truck driver, a firearm is probably necessary for the purpose of self-defense. So there are obviously certain circumstances where a firearm can be necessary.

As far as I’m concerned, having to justify your need of a firearm is the right way to go.[/quote]
I agree, owning a firearm should need a justifiable reason. I still think we should have compulsory military training. It’d give these yappos a wake up call. I’m not suggesting they be forced to go and fight, but I’m saying they should be ready fight. A country like Australia where numbers are lacking, I don’t think a strong Militia would hurt.
